title: Intro to React
description: Everything you need to know to start React from scratch.

sections.content: React is a powerful JavaScript library for building user interfaces. In this comprehensive guide, I'll walk you through the fundamentals of React development.
What is React?
React is a declarative, efficient, and flexible JavaScript library for building user interfaces. It lets you compose complex UIs from small and isolated pieces of code called 'components'.
Key Concepts
Getting Started

npx create-react-app my-app
cd my-app
npm start
This will create a new React project with all the necessary dependencies and start the development server.
Your First Component
This simple example shows how components work in React. The Welcome component receives props and renders them in JSX.
State Management
State allows components to manage their own data and re-render when that data changes.
Best Practices

items: Extract reusable logic into custom hooks

sections.content: React is an excellent choice for building modern web applications. Its component-based architecture and rich ecosystem make it a powerful tool for developers.

title: GDnet Project Overview
description: How I made my minimalistic educational Deep Learning framework using CuPy for GPU acceleration

sections.content: Kick off

I always wanted to understand how deep learning frameworks like TensorFlow or PyTorch really worked. So I dove into the math and wrote a basic NumPy-based neural net.

At first, I thought: â€œEasy â€” just WÂ·X + B and boom, done.â€

That was just the forward pass.

Then came backpropagation â€” and the math nearly broke me. Thatâ€™s where the real magic is. Once I understood it, building layers was straightforward â€” just abstracted groups of neurons.

Then came batching. I had no clue what it wasâ€¦ until my model took 10 minutes per epoch. Turns out, batching wasnâ€™t optional â€” it was necessary.

That was just the beginning!
Success!? MNIST came back with 95% accuracy ğŸ¤¯

I was shocked â€” 95% accuracy on MNIST! Total dopamine rush. I had only implemented basic layers: Dense, ReLU, Softmax, and batching.

Then I discovered CNNs. Everyone said they boosted accuracy, so I jumped in.

Implementing convolutions was chaos. I kinda understood the theory, but putting it into code? Painful. I ended up writing a 5-deep for-loop ğŸ˜µ. Training time exploded to 5+ hours.

I knew I had to vectorize it. Tried using NumPy â€” didnâ€™t go well.
Roadblock?! How to stand on the shoulders of giants

I kept wondering how frameworks like TensorFlow were so fast.

My code took 20 minutes per epoch on MNIST â€” TF? One second.

I realized they werenâ€™t cheating â€” just optimizing everything under the hood in C/C++.

So I 'cheated' too: I used PyTorch convolutions. But I still implemented im2col, col2im, and optimized other internals myself.

And after all that?

98% accuracy on MNIST. Felt like standing on the shoulders of giantsâ€¦ while wearing DIY shoes.
So I implemented this â€” when did the reality hit?

I was hyped. 98% on MNIST.

So I built a Tkinter UI and tried testing it with my own handwriting.

The model failed. Badly.

Thatâ€™s when it hit me â€” test accuracy doesnâ€™t mean real-world accuracy.

I dove into production ML concepts and found data augmentation. Implementing flips, shifts, and rotations was fine. Zooming? Absolute nightmare ğŸ’€

But it worked. After retraining, accuracy dropped to 96.9%, but generalization massively improved.

Now it was correctly predicting 9/10 digits.

ğŸ¥³ Redemption.
Next steps? Language processing âœ”ï¸

I got bored of image data. MNIST, EMNIST â€” all felt the same.

So I jumped into NLP. Built a `TextManager` using `TfidfVectorizer` to convert text to numbers.

I grabbed a Kaggle dataset to classify hate speech. Since I already had Softmax and CrossEntropy, it felt easy.

Then it all broke.

No matter what I typed â€” the model always said â€œhate speech.â€

Turns out the dataset was 85% hate, 15% normal. Total class imbalance.

I learned a tough lesson: NLP isnâ€™t image classification with words. I tried using class weights, tweaking losses â€” but nothing pushed accuracy past 20% on non-hate examples.

So yeahâ€¦ NLP dreams postponed. ğŸª¦
Idk anymore. Focused on other projects for a while

After a break, I circled back to GDNet. But I was kinda lost.

Then I remembered a side project â€” weather prediction.

Time series seemed fun, so I learned about RNNs and LSTMs. Wrote a full LSTM model.

Felt greatâ€¦ until YouTube betrayed me with:

â€œWhy RNNs Are Bad?â€

â€œWhat Replaced LSTMs?â€

I watched them and learned about **Attention** â€” and the legendary paper, â€œAttention Is All You Need.â€

I was hooked.

I built Transformer blocks: MultiHeadAttention, LayerNorm, FFN, all of it.

Trained a tiny GPT-like model:

- 100k tokens
- 30k vocab
- 10 epochs
- ~30% accuracy
- Estimated 67 days to train a proper one ğŸ’€

Tried matrix decomposition on the attention layers to speed things up â€” worked *a little*.

Then I tried reusing my CNN model...

It broke everything.

My â€œframeworkâ€ was a 1.1k-line Python file stitched with hope ğŸ˜‚
I sat and modularized my modules for the next 5 hours

Thankfully, the whole codebase was just 1.1k lines â€” but refactoring still hurt.

As I cleaned up, I realized I had been obsessed with layers, and ignored the rest:

- ğŸ§  Optimizers (SGD isnâ€™t everything)
- ğŸ”¢ Activation functions beyond ReLU
- ğŸ“‰ Loss functions
- ğŸ“ Regularization techniques

So I went all in â€” explored everything. The framework finally started to feel legit.

If you're curious how DL frameworks actually work â€” feel free to check it out!

Yeah, the code is messy (handcrafted with love ğŸ˜…), but readable, and easy to follow with a quick web search.
